text: Applies thin feathery like fine displacement noise to a fog volume.

This will add a noise displacement pattern to a volume field in order to create a thin, wispy broken-up cloud like appearance.
Various noise shaping options are available as well as masking controls. This node can also be used with a cloud volume displaced by
to add wispy details blown out from the cloud by the wind. By providing a surface volume on the second input, you can control the strength of the wispy details based on the distance of the cloud.
Provides a source volume for the wispy displacement.
The second input provides a signed distance field input that can be used to influence the overall wispy displacement. When working with a cloud generated by
, this allows you to control the wind strength that can be stronger the further away the voxel is from the cloud surface.
Make sure the signed distance field has enough expanded activated voxels to cover the area of the wispy noise displacement.
The third input provides an optional mask using the blend between the original input volume and the modified volume by this node.
When this checkbox turned on, use the blend between the original input volume (given by

) and to modified volume by this node.
    Setting this value to
means that this node will not have an effect on the input volume. Optionally, you can provide a mask volume (given by
) to mask specific regions in the volume field.
Negates the fog volume mask from the second input, if any.
Controls the number of displacement iterations. More iterations can create larger wispy displacement. Doing more than one iteration will slow down the cooking process.
When this is turned on, the input volume is combined with the displaced volume in each iteration.
The number of substeps to take in each iteration. Larger values can smooth out the fine details.
When this checkbox is on, overwrites the visualization for the volume.
Controls how to shade the volume. When generating cloud patterns, use
to see all the finer details and
to display clouds in a more realistic manner.
Uses ambient shadowing to display the volume.
Reverses the ambient shadowing for volumes which can be used to give a more realistic cloud look with internal scattering.

Fixed multiplier on the density field to control how opaque the volume is.
    If you are using a larger scene scale, you may need a smaller density scale.

Fog density is density per unit length, and is independent of the 
        resolution. So the same sized box, at 100 or 10 divisions, should be the
        same opacity. This means very small boxes will become transparent,
        especially if HDR rendering isn’t on. You can enable HDR rendering on
        the

format to at least 16-bit for 3D textures
        can also help resolve low-density volumes. These settings can be found
        under the
Determines the intensity of self shadows from ambient light sources. The final amount of self-shadowing from these lights is controlled by the product of
. The video demonstrates the value increasing from 0 to 1.
Turning off this checkbox does not disable ambient shadowing. Instead, it keeps this property of the geometry unchanged. If no
controls the default amount of self-shadowing from ambient lights.
The default headlight is treated as an ambient source by fog volumes.

Color of smoke that’s receiving direct light from an ambient light source.
    The default white setting indicates that areas exposed to external lights
    are bright. You can set this darker than

to achieve a
    more cloud-like look, where areas deeper within the cloud experience more
    light scattering and thus appear brighter.

must be
    enabled to control this parameter.

Color of smoke that’s not receiving any light from an ambient light source.
    The default black setting indicates that areas occluded from light are dark.
    You can set this brighter than

to achieve a more
    cloud-like appearance, where areas deeper within the cloud (that is, those
    occluded from outside light) are more luminous due to a greater degree of
    internal scattering.

must be enabled to control this
    parameter.
The type of noise to generate. Different algorithms give noise with different characteristics.
The default. A faster and more interesting variant of Perlin noise.
Sparse Convolution noise is similar to Worley noise. Does not have artifacts at grid points.
Produces a bumpy output. Named for its alleged resemblance to alligator skin.
A noise where the visual details are the same size.
A noise that’s stable over time, like a rotated Perlin noise, useful to create noise that seems to swirl and flow smoothly across time. Use the
parameter below to control the rotation.
A noise similar to Perlin but the noise lattice is on a tetrahedral mesh rather than a grid.  This can avoid the grid patterns often visible in Perlin noise.
Produces cellular features similar to plant cells, ocean waves, honeycombs, cratered landscapes, and so on.
A variant of Worley noise that produces blunted and cornered features.
A variant of Worley F1 noise that uses Manhattan distance calculation. Useful when you want unusual-looking noise.
A variant of Worley F2-F1 noise that uses Manhattan distance calculation. Useful when you want unusual-looking noise.
A variant of Worley F1 noise that uses Chebyshev distance calculation. Useful when you want unusual-looking noise.
A variant of Worley F2-F1 noise that uses Chebyshev distance calculation. Useful when you want unusual-looking noise.
Generates perlin noise based cloud pattern influenced by the
Generates simplex noise based cloud pattern influenced by the
parameter. Simplex noise similar to Perlin, but the noise lattice is on a tetrahedral mesh rather than a grid.  This can avoid the grid patterns often visible in Perlin noise.
Generates fast simplex noise based cloud pattern influenced by the
parameter. This simplex noise function uses a different lattice structure and a cheaper accumulation method.
Controls the effect of the distortion, large values will create larger wispy details in the pattern, but might create unrealistic looking cloud patterns.
Per Component button for separate amplitudes along each axis.
Specifies which vector components will be changed by the amplitude.
Per Component button, this lets you scale the
Uniform scale of elements in the noise.
Per Component button for separate scales along each axis.
Per Component button, this lets you scale the
Offset within the evaluated noise field (added to each axis). If you have the general noise effect you want, but want to get a different set of values for a different look, try changing the offset.
You can animate the noise using an expression such as
here. This is faster to compute than
, but gives the visual effect of
across the noise field, which may or may not be acceptable.
Per Component button for separate additional offsets along each axis.
Per Component button, this lets you add the a separate offset along each axis.
The number of iterations of distortion to add to the output of the basic noise. The more iterations you add, the more

the output. Note that the output may have fewer octaves than this parameter (that is, increasing the parameter will eventually stop adding detail), because the node eventually stops when there’s no more room to add more detail in the output.
The scale increment between iterations of fractal noise added to the basic output. The higher the value the larger the
added to the output. You can use a negative value for roughness.
Controls the resolution of the curl noise function used to generate the noise. A lower value will lead to tighter spirals in the noise.
Applies additional noise offset to the main noise to create finer details.
The type of noise to generate. Different algorithms give noise with different characteristics.
The default. A faster and more interesting variant of Perlin noise.
Sparse Convolution noise is similar to Worley noise. Does not have artifacts at grid points.
Produces a bumpy output. Named for its alleged resemblance to alligator skin.
A noise where the visual details are the same size.
A noise that’s stable over time, like a rotated Perlin noise, useful to create noise that seems to swirl and flow smoothly across time. Use the
parameter below to control the rotation.
A noise similar to Perlin but the noise lattice is on a tetrahedral mesh rather than a grid.  This can avoid the grid patterns often visible in Perlin noise.
Produces cellular features similar to plant cells, ocean waves, honeycombs, cratered landscapes, and so on.
A variant of Worley noise that produces blunted and cornered features.
A variant of Worley F1 noise that uses Manhattan distance calculation. Useful when you want unusual-looking noise.
A variant of Worley F2-F1 noise that uses Manhattan distance calculation. Useful when you want unusual-looking noise.
A variant of Worley F1 noise that uses Chebyshev distance calculation. Useful when you want unusual-looking noise.
A variant of Worley F2-F1 noise that uses Chebyshev distance calculation. Useful when you want unusual-looking noise.

Generates simplex noise based cloud pattern influenced by the
parameter. Simplex noise similar to Perlin, but the noise lattice is on a tetrahedral mesh rather than a grid.  This can avoid the grid patterns often visible in Perlin noise.
Generates fast simplex noise based cloud pattern influenced by the
parameter. This simplex noise function uses a different lattice structure and a cheaper accumulation method.
Controls the effect of the advection. Large values will advect the noise more. This is a multiplier on the noise amplitude (given by
Per Component button for separate amplitudes along each axis.
Per Component button, this lets you scale the
Uniform scale of elements in the noise. This is a multiplier on the noise element size (given by
Per Component button for a separate element size scale along each axis.
Per Component button, this lets you scale the

Offset within the evaluated advection noise field (added to each axis). If you have the general noise effect you want, but want to get a different set of values for a different look, try changing the offset.
Per Component button for a separate offset along each axis.
Per Component button, this lets you add a separate offset along each axis.
The number of iterations of distortion to add to the output of the basic noise. The more iterations you add, the more

the output. Note that the output may have fewer octaves than this parameter (that is, increasing the parameter will eventually stop adding detail), because the node eventually stops when there’s no more room to add more detail in the output.
The scale increment between iterations of fractal noise added to the basic output. The higher the value the larger the
added to the output. You can use a negative value for roughness.
When this is turned on, a directional force is added to the generated wispy noise to simulate the effect of a directional wind.
Controls the strength of the wind. Values that are too large could destroy the fine wispy details.
Controls the direction of the wind force.
When you apply wind to billowy clouds (created by

), this allows scaling the strength of the wind based on the signed distance field (provided in the second input of this node). Using this, the wispy details can be pulled more and more toward the wind direction the further away they are from the surface of the cloud.
Controls the surface distance at which the wind strength is at zero.
Controls the surface distance at which the wind strength is at its maximum.
to change how the surface distance should scale the wind strength between the minimum and maximum distance.
The ramp’s vertical axis represents the strength of the effect and the horizontal axis represents the surface distance between

The generated wispy noise field produces vectors that can flow in all directions. When working with a billowy cloud, you might not want vectors pointing inwards in the cloud volume. When a signed distance surface is provided as the second input, this controls how much each vector should point towards the surface normal instead based on the distance from the cloud surface.
Controls the surface distance at which the reflection strength is at zero.
Controls the surface distance at which the reflection strength is at its maximum.
to change how the surface distance should scale the reflection strength between the minimum and maximum distance.
The ramp’s vertical axis represents the strength of the effect and the horizontal axis represents the surface distance between
Scales the overall strength of the wispy noise based on the distance from the cloud surface when a signed distance field is provided in the second input.
Controls the surface distance at which the wispy strength is at zero.
Controls the surface distance at which the wispy strength is at its maximum.
to change how the surface distance should scale the wispy strength between the minimum and maximum distance.
The ramp’s vertical axis represents the strength of the effect and the horizontal axis represents the surface distance between
Scales the overall strength of the wispy noise based on the distance along a bound direction.
The direction in world space to use to scale the wispy noise strength.
Controls the bound limit along the bound direction (given by
) at which the wispy strength is at zero.
Controls the bound limit along the bound direction (given by
) at which the wispy strength is at its maximum.
to change how the bound distance should scale the wispy strength between
The ramp’s vertical axis represents the strength of the effect and the horizontal axis represents the bound distance between
Scales the overall strength of the wispy noise based on incoming density volume.
Controls the incoming density value at which the wispy strength is at zero.
Controls the incoming density value at which the wispy strength is at its maximum.
to change how the incoming density value should scale the wispy strength between
The ramp’s vertical axis represents strength of the effect and the horizontal axis represents the incoming density between
The name of the volume to be used as density for generating the wispy noise. Usually you should leave it as
The name of the volume to be used as signed distance field for generating the wispy noise. Usually you should leave it as

title: Cloud Wispy Noise
summary: Applies thin feathery like fine displacement noise to a fog volume.
